q: What are the main symptoms of an insect bite or sting?
a: The main symptoms of an insect bite or sting are pain where you were bitten or stung and a small, swollen lump on the skin. There may also be a mark on your skin where you were bitten or stung.

q: How can I remove a bee, wasp or hornet stinger?
a: To remove a bee, wasp or hornet stinger, brush or scrape the stinger sideways with your fingernail or the edge of a bank card. Do not use tweezers to pull out the stinger as it may squeeze out the poison. Wash the area with soap and water.

q: What should I do if I find a tick on my skin?
a: To remove a tick, use fine-tipped tweezers or a tick-removal tool to grasp the tick as close to the skin as possible. Slowly pull upwards, taking care not to squeeze the tick or leave any of its mouth in your skin. Clean the bite with antiseptic or soap and water.

q: How should I remove caterpillar hairs from my skin?
a: To remove caterpillar hairs from your skin, gently use tweezers or a pen to remove the caterpillar. Rinse your skin with running water and allow it to air dry. Use sticky tape on the skin to pick up any remaining hairs. Take off any jewellery and wash your clothes at a high temperature.

q: What can I do to ease the symptoms of an insect bite or sting?
a: To ease the symptoms of an insect bite or sting, you can put an ice pack wrapped in a cloth or a clean cloth soaked in cold water on the bite or sting for at least 20 minutes. You can also take painkillers, use antihistamines to relieve itching, and apply hydrocortisone cream to reduce itching and swelling.

q: What can a pharmacist advise me about insect bites and stings?
a: A pharmacist can advise you about medicines that can help ease the symptoms of a bite or sting, such as antihistamines, steroid creams, and painkillers. You can find a pharmacy for further assistance.

q: When should I ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 for an insect bite or sting?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111 if your symptoms worsen or are not getting any better, if you were stung in your mouth or throat or near your eyes, if you have severe tummy pain or are vomiting, if you feel dizzy or lightheaded, or if a large area around the bite or sting becomes red and swollen.

q: When should I call 999 for an insect bite or sting?
a: You should call 999 if your lips, mouth, throat, or tongue suddenly become swollen, if you're having difficulty breathing, if your throat feels tight or you're struggling to swallow, if your skin, tongue, or lips turn blue, grey, or pale, if you suddenly become confused or drowsy, if someone faints and cannot be woken up, or if you or the person who's unwell has a swollen, raised, or itchy rash.

q: What are the signs of a serious allergic reaction to an insect bite or sting?
a: The signs of a serious allergic reaction to an insect bite or sting include a sudden swelling of the lips, mouth, throat, or tongue, difficulty breathing, a tight throat or difficulty swallowing, skin, tongue, or lip discoloration, confusion or drowsiness, fainting, and a swollen, raised, or itchy rash. Immediate treatment in hospital may be necessary.

q: Can insect bites or stings cause illnesses?
a: Yes, insect bites or stings can cause illnesses. For example, ticks can cause Lyme disease, mites can cause scabies, and mosquitoes can cause malaria in certain parts of the world.

q: What are the main symptoms of an insect bite or sting?
a: The main symptoms of an insect bite or sting are pain at the site of the bite or sting and a small, swollen lump on the skin. There may also be redness and a mark where the bite or sting occurred.

q: How can I remove a bee, wasp, or hornet stinger from my skin?
a: To remove a bee, wasp, or hornet stinger, you can brush or scrape it sideways with your fingernail or the edge of a bank card. Do not use tweezers as it may squeeze out more poison. After removal, wash the area with soap and water.

q: What should I do if I have been bitten by a tick?
a: If you've been bitten by a tick, use fine-tipped tweezers or a tick-removal tool to grasp the tick as close to the skin as possible. Slowly pull upwards, taking care not to squeeze the tick or leave any parts of its mouth in your skin. Clean the bite with antiseptic or soap and water.

q: How can I remove caterpillar hairs from my skin?
a: To remove caterpillar hairs from your skin, gently use tweezers or a pen to remove the caterpillar. Rinse your skin with running water and air dry it. Use sticky tape to pick up any remaining hairs. Take off any jewelry and wash your clothes at a high temperature.

q: What can I do to ease the symptoms of an insect bite or sting?
a: To ease the symptoms of an insect bite or sting, you can apply an ice pack wrapped in a cloth or a clean cloth soaked in cold water for at least 20 minutes. You can also take painkillers, use antihistamines for itching (except if there were caterpillar hairs on the skin), and apply hydrocortisone cream for itching and swelling.

q: What can a pharmacist do to help with insect bites and stings?
a: A pharmacist can advise you about medicines that can help ease the symptoms of insect bites and stings, such as antihistamines, steroid creams, and painkillers. They can also provide guidance on proper treatment and recommend over-the-counter remedies.

q: When should I ask for an urgent GP appointment or seek help from NHS 111 after being bitten or stung by an insect?
a: You should ask for an urgent GP appointment or seek help from NHS 111 if your symptoms worsen or are not improving, if you were stung in the mouth or throat or near your eyes, if you have severe tummy pain or vomiting, if a large area around the bite or sting becomes red and swollen, if you have a high temperature and swollen glands, if you have had a serious allergic reaction to an insect bite or sting before, or if you were stung more than once.

q: When should I call 999 after being bitten or stung by an insect?
a: You should call 999 if your lips, mouth, throat, or tongue suddenly become swollen, if you are having difficulty breathing or breathing very fast, if your throat feels tight or you are struggling to swallow, if your skin, tongue, or lips turn blue, grey, or pale, if you suddenly become confused, drowsy, or dizzy, if you or someone else faints and cannot be woken up, or if a child is limp, floppy, or not responding as usual. These can be signs of a serious allergic reaction and may require immediate treatment in the hospital.

q: What are the symptoms of a serious allergic reaction to an insect bite or sting?
a: Symptoms of a serious allergic reaction to an insect bite or sting include swollen lips, mouth, throat, or tongue, rapid or labored breathing, tight throat or difficulty swallowing, blue, grey, or pale skin, confusion, drowsiness, dizziness, rash that is swollen, raised, or itchy, and loss of consciousness. Immediate medical attention is needed if these symptoms occur.

q: Do home remedies like bicarbonate of soda help with insect bites and stings?
a: No, home remedies like bicarbonate of soda are not recommended for treating insect bites and stings. It is best to follow proper care instructions such as cleaning the area, applying ice, taking painkillers, and using antihistamines or hydrocortisone cream as appropriate. If symptoms worsen or become severe, medical help should be sought.
